preview_html:
Manchester United and Manchester City are set for another tightly contested Manchester derby at Old Trafford, with both teams keen to assert their status in the Premier League. History, form, and recent meetings between the two sides point towards a complex tactical battle rather than an outright shootout.

The previous clash between these two sides saw Manchester City establish firm control with a convincing 3-0 win on home soil. Despite Manchester United's higher possession rate of 55%, City displayed ruthless efficiency. Phil Foden opened the scoreline in the 18th minute, with Erling Haaland adding a brace in the second half (53rd and 68th minutes). While United outnumbered City in overall shots (12 to 13), their efforts yielded only two on target compared to City's six, underlining the decisive quality up front for the defending champions.

The dangerous attack count favored United by 64 to 34, but City proved far more clinical in both penalty areas. The previous encounter exemplified recent trends, as United have now failed to win in 18 of their last 20 matches against City, with 45% of those resulting in defeats by a margin of two or more goals.

Turning to recent form, Manchester United's last six matches in all competitions have seen them claim just one victory, alongside four draws and a loss. They have averaged 1.67 goals scored and 1.67 conceded per match, indicating both competitive matches and defensive lapses. Draws have been a recurring theme, with seven from their last twelve outings, and they are currently undefeated in ten of those fixtures. However, an 83% winless rate in their last six matches underlines the struggles to claim all three points.

At Old Trafford, United's recent home record offers a glimmer of encouragement. They have drawn two and won one of their last three, scoring an average of two goals per game. In their last eleven league matches at home, they have stayed undefeated in 82% of them, showing improved resilience in familiar surroundings.

Manchester City, by contrast, maintain a more formidable run. Their last six matches yielded three wins and three draws, with no losses. A potent attack continues to deliver (1.5 goals per match), and a solid defense has allowed only 0.5 goals per game in this period. With 85% undefeated in their last forty matches across all competitions, City have also managed to win by two or more goals in 40% of their last ten fixtures. Their last twelve away matches have ended in ten without defeat.

Recent meetings between the two clubs have not always been one-sided, with two draws in their last four head-to-heads. Nonetheless, City's superiority, especially in critical moments, remains a strong narrative thread in this rivalry.

As for probable lineups, both teams look set to field largely familiar faces with no significant sidelined absences reported heading into the fixture.

Manchester United

Goalkeeper: Senne Lammens

Defenders: Diogo Dalot, Lisandro Martínez, Ayden Heaven, Luke Shaw

Midfielders: Casemiro, Manuel Ugarte, Matheus Cunha, Patrick Dorgu, Joshua Zirkzee

Attackers: Benjamin Sesko

The 4-2-3-1 formation has offered United a balance between defensive cover and attacking diversity, with the midfield expected to play a crucial role in disrupting City's rhythm and controlling transitions.

Manchester City

Goalkeeper: Gianluigi Donnarumma

Defenders: Rúben Dias, Nathan Aké, Matheus Nunes, Nico O'Reilly

Midfielders: Rodri, Bernardo Silva, Rayan Cherki, Phil Foden, Tijjani Reijnders

Attackers: Erling Haaland

Guardiola's side have consistently lined up in a 4-1-4-1 formation, relying on Rodri's protection ahead of the defense and Foden and Silva's creativity to support Haaland's predatory instincts.

From a statistical perspective, City’s defensive strength and proficiency away from home (43% clean sheets over the last thirty away games) stacks up well against United's struggle for wins. However, United's strong home record and City's run of three consecutive draws in their last three matches suggest there is little to separate them coming in.

Prediction leans toward a draw as the most probable outcome, assessed at 39% likelihood, with a scoreline of 1-1 reflecting both sides’ tendencies in recent outings. Given United’s resilience at Old Trafford and City's formidable consistency, this looks set to be a contest defined by margins and moments rather than dominance.

Sunderland take on Crystal Palace at the Stadium of Light in the Premier League with both teams looking to get back on track after a sequence of stalemates and narrow defeats. With neither side in prolific scoring form recently, a tight contest could be in store.

Heading into the fixture, a closer look at their recent head to head matches reveals that Sunderland have held a slight edge. In the last five encounters between these sides, Sunderland have posted two wins and two draws, losing just once to Palace.

This points to a history of closely fought battles, with Sunderland successfully keeping Crystal Palace at bay in a number of recent meetings. The last four duels saw two draws, again reflecting the cautious approach both sides often employ against each other.

Sunderland's position of 10th in the standings can be attributed to a sturdy defence but also a lack of punch up front. Over 21 league matches, they have secured seven wins, nine draws and suffered five losses, averaging one goal scored per game and conceding 1.05. The squad's tendency to draw matches has become a notable pattern, evidenced by 58% of their last 12 fixtures in all competitions ending level.

More telling is Sunderland's current winless run. They have failed to win in each of their last five matches in all competitions and remain winless in 10 of their last 12. At home, however, they've proven tough to break down, undefeated in 11 of their last 12 matches at the Stadium of Light, though the majority have ended up as draws.

Crystal Palace's journey this season has followed a remarkably similar trajectory. Sitting 13th, the Eagles have mirrored Sunderland's tally of seven wins from 21 matches, with seven draws and seven defeats. Their goal output stands at 1.05 per match, while conceding 1.1 per game, reflected in a nearly identical goal difference to the Black Cats.

Their recent form paints a bleaker picture. Palace haven't won any of their last eight matches in all competitions and are winless in eight of their last 10. Away from home, they've been inconsistent, splitting their most recent 18 Premier League matches evenly with nine wins and nine others not yielding maximum points. Notably, Palace have managed a clean sheet in 43% of their last 40 away matches, showing some defensive resilience.

Home and away form comparisons highlight Sunderland's ability to grind out results on their turf. In the last three league matches at the Stadium of Light, Sunderland have won one and drawn two, keeping their opponents to an average of just 0.33 goals per game. Palace, on the other hand, have struggling on their travels recently, with two defeats and a draw in their last three away fixtures while averaging just 0.67 goals scored.

Tactical setups are likely to mirror those used in recent outings. Sunderland’s last three matches saw them shuffle between a 4-2-3-1 and 4-4-2, but consistency in personnel points toward a return to the 4-2-3-1. Crystal Palace have favoured a 3-4-2-1 in each of their last three games, which has brought solidity, even if goals have been scarce.

Sunderland Predicted Starting Lineup:

Goalkeeper: Robin Roefs

Defenders: Dennis Cirkin, Nordi Mukiele, Omar Alderete, Trai Hume

Midfielders: Lutsharel Geertruida, Simon Adingra, Enzo Le Fée, Granit Xhaka, Eliezer Mayenda

Attackers: Brian Brobbey

Crystal Palace Predicted Starting Lineup:

Goalkeeper: Dean Henderson

Defenders: Marc Guéhi, Maxence Lacroix, Jefferson Lerma

Midfielders: Nathaniel Clyne, Tyrick Mitchell, Adam Wharton, Will Hughes

Attackers: Yéremy Pino, Justin Devenny

Forward: Jean-Philippe Mateta

Given both clubs' tendencies to share the points and recent records indicating low goal returns, it shouldn't surprise if this clash goes down to fine margins. Sunderland have kept three home clean sheets in their last seven while Palace have posted 43% clean sheets in their last 40 away games. Both teams average less than 1 goal per match in their last 6 fixtures.

The probability of a draw in this matchup stands at 42%, as neither team has shown enough offensive power to suggest a sudden outburst. Sunderland's home resilience, coupled with Palace’s away discipline and the pattern established in recent meetings, points to another low-scoring, strategic contest. A 0-0 outcome fits the narrative, and the statistics give plenty of reason to expect another closely matched affair.

There’s a sense of pressure building as Tottenham gear up to host West Ham at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium. Both sides are desperate to arrest negative trends, and the numbers behind their campaigns set up a matchup where quality will need to rise above inconsistency.

Tottenham return to their home turf amid a period of indifferent form. Under Thomas Frank, the side has registered just one victory over their last six matches. With two draws and three defeats in that span, Tottenham’s struggles are reflected in their average of just 0.83 goals scored per game, while conceding 1.5 on the other end.

The home record tells a slightly more positive story: in their last three at the Tottenham Hotspur Stadium, Spurs have averaged 1.67 goals scored and conceded just one, securing a win, a draw, and a loss.

Zooming out to the Premier League standings, Tottenham find themselves 14th after 21 fixtures. With 7 wins, 6 draws, and 8 losses, their goal difference sits at +3, and their scoring rate of 1.43 per game outpaces their defensive yield of 1.29. Still, inconsistency has been a recurring theme as they have lost 50% of their last 12 league matches and are winless in 10 of those.

For West Ham, Graham Potter’s side sits in a more precarious position. Currently 18th in the table, West Ham have only managed 3 wins across 21 matches. Losses have mounted—13 already—with a sharp negative goal difference at -21 and only 1.05 goals scored per game. Worse still, the Hammers have conceded an average of more than 2 goals per fixture.

Recent history provides little comfort for West Ham. They are winless in 10 of their last 10 outings in all competitions, losing five times and drawing just once in their last six, scoring at the same 0.83 per game rate as their hosts but faring worse at the back with 2.33 conceded per match. Their away record continues the trend: winless in 12 of their last 15 away clashes and losing 43% of their last 7 away games by 2 or more goals.

Historically, this fixture has been one Tottenham have often controlled. Across their last 10 meetings with West Ham, Spurs have emerged victorious five times and drawn three, losing just two.

Home trends are less flattering for Tottenham, who have failed to win in 20 of their last 25 Premier League matches on their patch, but have managed to score in bursts, winning by two or more in 3 of their most recent 7 home games.

The tactical setups for both managers look largely set. Tottenham frequently lined up in a 4-2-3-1 or 4-3-3 in their last three matches without any sidelined players on the injury list. West Ham consistently adopted a 4-2-3-1. Based on regular starters, expected formations, and recent substitutions, here is the most probable lineup for each side:

Tottenham:

Goalkeeper: Guglielmo Vicario

Defenders: Pedro Porro, Cristian Romero, Micky van de Ven, Djed Spence

Midfielders: Rodrigo Bentancur, Archie Gray, João Palhinha, Mathys Tel, Wilson Odobert

Attackers: Richarlison

West Ham:

Goalkeeper: Alphonse Areola

Defenders: Kyle Walker-Peters, Jean-Clair Todibo, Maximilian Kilman, Oliver Scarles

Midfielders: Jarrod Bowen, Mateus Fernandes, Soungoutou Magassa, Freddie Potts, Lucas Paquetá

Attackers: Callum Wilson

Key trends suggest Tottenham’s attack may find more success than West Ham’s, especially given Spurs average more shots and possession at home compared to West Ham’s productivity on the road. While West Ham have drawn four of their last eight on their travels, defensive vulnerabilities away from home persist.

As for the outcome, Forebet’s algorithm gives Tottenham a 47% likelihood of notching all three points, with a 2-1 scoreline predicted. Given West Ham’s sustained winless spell and Tottenham’s stronger head-to-head record, this projection appears justified. With both teams under pressure, the onus will be on Tottenham to capitalise on home advantage and break their recent league winless streak.
